awd_titl_txt: CPS: Small: Integrated Reconfigurable Control and Moving Target Defense for Secure Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Cyber-physical systems (CPS) are engineered systems created as networks of interacting physical and computational processes. Most modern products in major industrial sectors, such as automotive, avionics, medical devices, and power systems already are or rapidly becoming CPS driven by new requirements and competitive pressures. However, in recent years, a number of successful cyber attacks against CPS targets, some of which have even caused severe physical damage, have demonstrated that security and resilience of CPS is a very critical problem, and that new methods and technologies are required to build dependable systems. Modern automotive vehicles, for example, employ sensors such as laser range finders and cameras, GPS and inertial measurement units, on-board computing, and network connections all of which contribute to vulnerabilities that can be exploited for deploying attacks with possibly catastrophic consequences. Securing such systems requires that potential points of compromise and vehicle-related data are protected. In order to fulfill the great promise of CPS technologies such as autonomous vehicles and realize the potential technological, economic, and societal impact, it is necessary to develop principles and methods that ensure the development of CPS capable of functioning dependably, safely, and securely. 

In view of these challenges, the project develops an approach for integration of reconfigurable control software design and moving target defense for CPS. The main idea is to improve CPS security by making the attack surface dynamic and unpredictable while ensuring safe behavior and correct functionality of the overall system. The proposed energy-based control design approach generates multiple alternatives of the software application that are robust to performance variability and uncertainty.  A runtime environment is designed to implement instruction set randomization, address space randomization, and data space randomization. The heart of the runtime environment is a configuration manager that can modify the software configuration, either proactively or reactively upon detection of attacks, while preserving the functionality and ensuring stable and safe CPS behavior. By changing the control software on-the-fly, the approach creates a cyber moving target and raises significantly the cost for a successful attack without impacting the essential behavior and functionality. Demonstration and experimental evaluation will be performed using a hardware-in-the-loop simulation testbed for automotive CPS.

por.por_cntn:
The automotive industry is shifting fast towards autonomous and connected vehicles. Over the past decade, increasing numbers of electronic control units (ECUs) that communicate via different types of communication buses are used to provide intelligent services and safety. With increasing connectivity, security and privacy have become pressing concerns. Researchers have shown that various systems can be hacked to enable a remote takeover of the vehicle. Attacks can be used to control a wide range of automotive functions, for example, cutting brakes, shutting down engines, and driving off road. Misbehaving cars can further affect other cars and transportation networks.

Memory corruption vulnerabilities are one of the most common attack vectors used to compromise software systems. Automotive software is not immune to such vulnerabilities. For example, there are multiple memory corruption vulnerabilities in a car’s telematics unit and media player.  Security researchers have revealed memory corruption vulnerabilities which are used in smart cars enable attackers to perform remote code execution and gain remote control. Moving target defense (MTD) plays an important role in improving the security of software against memory corruption vulnerabilities in a proactive fashion by adding uncertainty and complexity into the system to make it difficult for attackers to identify vulnerable components and exploit vulnerabilities. However, MTD techniques may incur considerable overhead in performance and cost, so they should be used in CPS only after careful consideration of the system requirements and evaluated in the context of all the functional and non-functional requirements.

This project developed a novel integrated approach for reconfigurable control design and MTD to secure CPS. At the control design layer, the objective is to design multiple alternative software configurations that satisfy the system requirements and are robust to implementation uncertainties. At the runtime environment, address space randomization (ASR), instruction set randomization (ISR), and data space randomization (DSR) are used to secure the system against various attacks. The integration of reconfigurable control design and runtime MTD methods protects the system against a large and important class of attacks while ensuring the desired CPS behavior and functionality. The impact is that instead of considering known attacks in known components, the proposed approach can harden a CPS against a large class of attacks. Although the project targeted CPS automotive vehicles, the findings can be generalized to other CPS applications with high-confidence control software such as power systems, medical devices, and smart buildings.

 

The project accomplished the following key results:

1.     Developed and demonstrated a model-based design methodology for automotive control software and safety analysis using port-Hamiltonian systems (PHS). PHS are used to model the vehicle dynamics, speed and steering control systems, and the interactions between physical and cyber components.

2.     Developed a reconfigurable control approach based on controllers designed using PHS, neural network controllers, and PID controllers, proposed a safety verification of CPS with neural network controllers, and demonstrated the approach using an advanced emergency braking system.

3.     Developed an approach for efficiently detecting out-of-distribution and adversarial sensor inputs in learning-enabled CPS. The approach is demonstrated using an advanced emergency braking system, a self-driving end-to-end controller, and real-world data set for autonomous driving.

4.     Developed a runtime environment using MTD techniques that combine ISR, ASR, and DSR to secure the system against various cyber-attacks while ensuring the functionality and the safe behavior of the overall system.

5.     Developed and implemented a mixed time and event triggered security architecture based on the ARINC 653 standard that provides predictable and reliable operation as well as rapid detection of attacks and reconfiguration to maintain safety.

6.     Evaluated the impact of cyber-attacks using hardware-in-the-loop testbeds with embedded hardware that is typical in automotive CPS and a simulation workstation to represent the vehicle and the physical environment.

7.     As part of the security evaluation, the project considered vulnerabilities that are unrelated to the CPS application but can compromise MTD-based techniques such rowhammer and other side channel attacks and developed an approach for detection of such attacks.

 

Key broader impact activities include:

1.     Dissemination and Outreach. The project generated 25 papers published in journals, conferences, and workshops. Highlights of the publications include four best paper awards.

2.     Professional Development. The project involved three graduate and two undergraduate students. Two PhD students completed their degrees with direct support from this project.

3.     Education. Material related to the project including research topics and student projects has been incorporated to an undergraduate class on cybersecurity at Vanderbilt University. The project participated into summer camps in CPS security for high-school students and teachers.

4.     Technology Transfer. As a result of this project and support from Vanderbilt University, a startup, ARMS Cyber Defense Inc., was founded and received additional funding to accelerate technology commercialization, innovation, and job creation.
